map.title: Cemeteries
map.decription: This map shows the locations of cemeteries on Pohnpei. The information was extracted by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017) from Digital Line Graphs (DLGs) of U.S. Geological Survey 1:25,000-scale topographic maps (2001).

map.title: Burial grounds
map.decription: This map shows the locations of burial grounds and gravesites on Yap. The dataset was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019) from separate layers digitized by the Queens University of Charlotte (2002-2004) based on 1983 topographic maps by the U.S. Geological Survey. The information contained is neither highly accurate nor complete and is subject to verification, updating, and appending as opportunities permit.

map.title: Cemeteries
map.decription: This map shows the locations of cemeteries on the islands in Chuuk Lagoon. The information was extracted by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) from Digital Line Graphs (DLGs) of U.S. Geological Survey 1:25,000-scale topographic maps (1996-1997).

map.title: Quarries

map.title: Quarries
map.decription: This map shows the location of the principal quarry on Kosrae. Smaller quarries exist and are not shown. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019) from KML file created by Joyminda Palokoa George (2019) specifically for this Digital Atlas.

map.title: Quarries and dredge sites
map.decription: This map shows the location of rock quarries and dredging basins on the islands in Chuuk Lagoon. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020), based on field verification and locations obtained from Geoview.

map.title: Designated protected areas
map.decription: This map shows the designated protected areas on and around Pohnpei. The dataset was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017) by merging information obtained from Pohnpei State Government, The Nature Conservancy, and KML files created by Alex Zuccarelli for Pohnpei Eco-Adventure Map Guide Series (2013). This GIS coverage may not be complete. Additional marine protected areas are referenced in legislation (e.g., https://www.fm/PohnpeiLeg/pending/PM_RD.doc) but may not have been delineated or formally implemented. Among sanctuaries that may exist in Pohnpei but are not yet included in these geospatial data are Sokehs Trochus Sanctuaries and Kepidau en Dauahk (Dawahk Pass) Marine Sanctuary.

map.title: Protected areas
map.decription: This map shows the designated protected areas on and around Kosrae. The dataset was created by the Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019) by merging information obtained from The Nature Conservancy and Kosrae Island Resource Management Authority (KIRMA). This GIS coverage may not be complete. Additional marine protected areas are referenced in legislation (e.g., https://www.fm/KosraeLeg/pending/PM_RD.doc) but may not have been delineated or formally implemented.

map.title: Protected areas
map.decription: This map shows the designated protected areas on and around Yap. The dataset was created by The Nature Conservancy. A subset to show only Yap was created by the Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019).

map.title: Designated protected areas

map.title: Areas of biodiversity significance
map.decription: This map shows the proposed protected areas on Pohnpei. The dataset was created by The Nature Conservancy based on the results of the workshop convened in 2014 by The Nature Conservancy (TNC), Conservation Society of Pohnpei (CSP), and Pohnpei State Governor’s Office to discuss the design of Pohnpei’s Protected Areas Network (PAN).

map.title: Areas of biodiversity significance
map.decription: This map shows the Areas of Biological Significance (ABS) on Kosrae. The dataset was created by The Nature Conservancy. A subset to show only Kosrae was created by the Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019). The polygons in the data are intended to capture those areas that represent the wide range of biodiversity features in the marine and terrestrial areas of FSM. They capture expert knowledge from the FSM Blueprint project. They are used to guide conservation planning and projects in FSM, and ultimately to help establish conservation areas.

The polygons in the data are intended to capture those areas that represent the wide range of biodiversity features in the marine and terrestrial areas of FSM. They capture expert knowledge from the FSM Blueprint project. They are used to guide conservation planning and projects in FSM, and ultimately to help establish conservation areas.

map.title: Species-level conservation targets
map.decription: This map shows the species-level conservation targets on Pohnpei. The geospatial data were created by The Nature Conservancy based on the results of the workshop convened in 2014 by The Nature Conservancy (TNC), Conservation Society of Pohnpei (CSP), and Pohnpei State Governor’s Office to discuss the design of Pohnpei’s Protected Areas Network (PAN). The original dataset could not be located by TNC so a new one was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017) by digitizing a hard copy map from the original workshop report.

map.title: Cultural landmarks
map.decription: This map shows some of the most significant cultural landmarks on Pohnpei. The data layer was formatted for GIS by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017), using exclusively KML files created by Alex Zuccarelli for Pohnpei Eco-Adventure Map Guide Series (2013).

map.title: Cultural landmarks
map.decription: This map shows some of the most significant cultural landmarks on Kosrae. The data layer was formatted for GIS by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019), using Excel spreadsheet information provided by Kosrae Island Resource Management Authority (KIRMA).

map.title: Cultural landmarks
map.decription: This map shows some of the significant cultural landmarks on Yap, specifically traditional buildings (p'eebaay, faeluw, or others), dancing grounds, and fish weirs. The map and the data behind it utilize information provided by Yap traditional owners and knowledge holders. The dataset was created by the Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019) by combining various data layers created by the Queens University of Charlotte, Yap Historic Preservation Office, and Yap Traditional Owners based on field work conducted in 2002 and 2003 as well as on on-screen digitizing of 1983 USGS topographic maps. The fish weir dataset was created by the Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019) based on tabular data provided by Dr. William F. Jeffery, who led the project financed with Yap State historic preservation funds in partnership with US National Park Service, US Department of the Interior. The information contained within is not complete and is subject to updating and appending as opportunities permit.

map.title: Prominent prehistoric sites
map.decription: This map shows some of the prominent prehistoric sites on Pohnpei. The data layer was formatted for GIS by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017), using exclusively KML files created by Alex Zuccarelli for Pohnpei Eco-Adventure Map Guide Series (2013).

map.title: Prominent prehistoric sites
map.decription: This map shows some of the prominent prehistoric sites on the islands in Chuuk Lagoon. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) by researching and combining location data from Chuuk State Historic Preservation Office, Geoview, Chuuk Visitors Bureau, US National Park Service, Rainbird (1993), and years of research (2001-2008) by William Jeffery (University of Guam) and fieldwork implemented with Arimichy Rudolph and Anerit Mailo of Chuuk State Historic Preservation Office (Chuuk SHPO), in collaboration with many people in Chuuk, including Gradvin Aisek, Tong Misa, and the other chiefs of Tonoas, informant and translator Joshua Suka, landowners and residents of Tonoas and Weno, and the US National Park Service / Historic Preservation Fund.

map.title: Nan Madol islets and buildings
map.decription: This map shows the islets and buildings at Pohnpei's premier prehistoric site, the ancient Saudeleur capital at Nan Madol. The data layer was formatted for GIS by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017), using exclusively KML files created by Alex Zuccarelli for Pohnpei Eco-Adventure Map Guide Series (2013).

map.title: Lelu ruins
map.decription: This map shows the islets and buildings at Kosrae's premier prehistoric site, the ancient Saudeleur capital at Nan Madol. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2019) by georeferencing and digitizing archaeological map [figure 8] from Cordy, R. 1993. The Lelu Stone Ruins (Kosrae, Micronesia): 1987-81 Historical and Archaeological Research. Honolulu: Social Science Research Institute, University of Hawai’i at Manoa.

map.title: Ancient subdivisions [Saudeleur times]
map.decription: This map shows the ancient subdivisions of Pohnpei, as they existed at the time of Saudeleur dynasty. The boundaries are highly approximate and were digitized by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017) from David L. Hanlon (1988), Upon a Stone Altar, University of Hawaii Press. Place name spellings are from Thomas Panholzer and Rufino Mauricio (2003), Place Names of Pohnpei Island, Bess Press.

map.title: Colonial period sites
map.decription: This map shows some of the key historic sites and remains from the Spanish, German, and Japanese periods of Pohnpei's history. The data layer was formatted for GIS by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017), using KML files created by Alex Zuccarelli for Pohnpei Eco-Adventure Map Guide Series (2013).

map.title: Colonial period sites
map.decription: This map shows some of the key historic sites from World War II and Japanese period of Yap's history. The data layer was formatted for GIS by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017), using KML files created by Joshua Libyan Tun specifically for this Digital Atlas.

map.title: German, Japanese, and TTPI sites
map.decription: This map shows some of the key historic sites and remains from the German, Japanese, and Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands periods of Chuuk's history. The features shown are remains of government, civilian, and mixed-used sites and exclude military installation and World War II remnants. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) by compiling location information from a number of sources, including Geoview and the years of research (2001-2008) by William Jeffery (University of Guam) and fieldwork implemented with Arimichy Rudolph and Anerit Mailo of Chuuk State Historic Preservation Office (Chuuk SHPO), in collaboration with many people in Chuuk, including Gradvin Aisek, Tong Misa, and the other chiefs of Tonoas, informant and translator Joshua Suka, landowners and residents of Tonoas and Weno, and the US National Park Service / Historic Preservation Fund.

map.title: Statues and monuments
map.decription: This map shows the statues and monuments on Pohnpei. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2017), from original KML files created by Alex Zuccarelli for Pohnpei Eco-Adventure Map Guide Series (2013) appended by field verification.

map.title: Monuments and museums
map.decription: This map shows the locations of memorial plaques, monuments, and musems on the islands in Chuuk Lagoon. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) using location data established by William Jeffery (University of Guam), Chuuk State Historic Preservation Office, Chuuk Visitors Bureau, and a number of other published and unpublished sources.

map.title: Japanese military installations
map.decription: This map shows the locations of a significant part of Japanese military and World War II legacy scattered around the islands of Chuuk Lagoon. The features shown are remains of military bases, command centers, runways, storage areas, artillery sites, bunkers, port facilities, seaplane sites, and other war paraphernalia located on land, as opposed to sunken ships and other underwater features. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) by compiling location information from a number of sources, including Geoview and years of research (2001-2008) by William Jeffery (University of Guam) and fieldwork implemented with Arimichy Rudolph and Anerit Mailo of Chuuk State Historic Preservation Office (Chuuk SHPO), in collaboration with many people in Chuuk, including Gradvin Aisek, Tong Misa, and the other chiefs of Tonoas, informant and translator Joshua Suka, landowners and residents of Tonoas and Weno, and the US National Park Service / Historic Preservation Fund.

map.title: Sunken ships and planes
map.decription: This map shows the locations of sunken ships, planes, and war debris in Chuuk Lagoon. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) from location data reported by Jeffery (2007), War graves, munition dumps and pleasure grounds: A post- colonial perspective of Chuuk Lagoon’s submerged World War II sites; as well as Jeffery (2012), The future of Chuuk Lagoon's submerged WW II sites. All dive sites shown here are sunken ships, planes, and related war remains. The layer includes all known ships sunken inside Chuuk Lagoon. It excludes locations of ships that were damaged but did not sink, ships that were sunk but later refloated, and ships that sunk outside Chuuk Lagoon.

map.title: Registered historic places [US NPS National Register of Historic Places and US National Historic Landmarks]
map.decription: This map shows the locations of sunken ships, planes, and war debris in Chuuk Lagoon. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) from location data reported by Jeffery (2007), War graves, munition dumps and pleasure grounds: A post- colonial perspective of Chuuk Lagoon’s submerged World War II sites; as well as Jeffery (2012), The future of Chuuk Lagoon's submerged WW II sites. All dive sites shown here are sunken ships, planes, and related war remains. The layer includes all known ships sunken inside Chuuk Lagoon. It excludes locations of ships that were damaged but did not sink, ships that were sunk but later refloated, and ships that sunk outside Chuuk Lagoon.

map.title: Tourism points of interest
map.decription: This map shows tourism points of interest, as considered and promoted by Chuuk Visitors Bureau. Sites include prominent hotels and dive shops, beaches and picnic sites, well known culturally-significant sites, World War II remains, and other locations of interest to visitors to Chuuk. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) in consultation with Douglas Marar (Chuuk Visitors Bureau) and using information provided in KML form by Nely Mori Ruben (Chuuk Visitors Bureau).

map.title: Lighthouses
map.decription: This map shows tourism points of interest, as considered and promoted by Chuuk Visitors Bureau. Sites include prominent hotels and dive shops, beaches and picnic sites, well known culturally-significant sites, World War II remains, and other locations of interest to visitors to Chuuk. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) in consultation with Douglas Marar (Chuuk Visitors Bureau) and using information provided in KML form by Nely Mori Ruben (Chuuk Visitors Bureau).

map.title: Wrecked and abandoned vessels [post World War II]
map.decription: This map shows the locations of wrecked and abandonded vessels in Chuuk Lagoon, especially ships that ran aground on the barrier reef and patch reefs. The data layer was created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) (2020) using a combination of field-collected information and observations using Google Maps and imagery. It should be noted that this layer is an incipient version that currently contains only one data point, but is slated for expansion in the near future as fieldwork opportunities permit.
